body_html:
@yaroslavvb thanks for the workaround!

For anyone else who doesn't see how switching the collection would work, here is an example

g = tf.get_default_graph()
s = tf.Variable("hi")
print("Global variables", tf.global_variables())
add_to_local = tf.add_to_collection(tf.GraphKeys.LOCAL_VARIABLES,s)
print("Local variables", tf.local_variables())
del g._collections[tf.GraphKeys.GLOBAL_VARIABLES][0]
print("Global variables", tf.global_variables())
print("Local variables", tf.local_variables())
body_text:
@yaroslavvb thanks for the workaround!
For anyone else who doesn't see how switching the collection would work, here is an example
g = tf.get_default_graph()
s = tf.Variable("hi")
print("Global variables", tf.global_variables())
add_to_local = tf.add_to_collection(tf.GraphKeys.LOCAL_VARIABLES,s)
print("Local variables", tf.local_variables())
del g._collections[tf.GraphKeys.GLOBAL_VARIABLES][0]
print("Global variables", tf.global_variables())
print("Local variables", tf.local_variables())
body:
@yaroslavvb thanks for the workaround! 

For anyone else who doesn't see how switching the collection would work, here is an example

```
g = tf.get_default_graph()
s = tf.Variable("hi")
print("Global variables", tf.global_variables())
add_to_local = tf.add_to_collection(tf.GraphKeys.LOCAL_VARIABLES,s)
print("Local variables", tf.local_variables())
del g._collections[tf.GraphKeys.GLOBAL_VARIABLES][0]
print("Global variables", tf.global_variables())
print("Local variables", tf.local_variables())
```
